channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Guards at Refugee Camps in Germany Are Accused of Abuse
item.description: The inquiry began after the appearance of images of mistreatment, including a guard with his foot on the back of a refugee’s neck.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: From Around the World, Support for Hong Kong Protesters
item.description: The democracy movement in Hong Kong is gripping people’s imaginations around the world and inspiring many small but impassioned demonstrations of support. Partly fueling them is the Asian city’s large diaspora.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Hong Kong House, the city's economic and trade office in Sydney, was plastered with notes of support for the Hong Kong demonstrators on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: To Beat China Censorship, Hong Kong Protesters Flock to Off-Grid Messaging App
item.description: The app, FireChat, which allows messaging without the use of cellular or Internet connections, gained use amid rumors that the Hong Kong government would cut off Internet access, according to protesters, though it is unlikely officials would make such a move.
item.category: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Demonstrators checked their cellphones on Nathan Road, a major route through Kowloon, on Monday.

item.title: Poisonous Conditions on Japanese Volcano Force Rescue Workers to Retreat
item.description: High levels of poisonous gases near the peak of Mount Ontake led to a suspension of rescue operations after eight more bodies were recovered.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Mount Ontake in central Japan continued to spew smoke and ash two days after it erupted.

item.title: Police Arrest Hundreds Over Religious Clashes in India
item.description: The riots, in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s home state, Gujarat, broke out after a Hindu man posted an image offensive to Muslims on Facebook.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: United Nations General Assembly: Benjamin Netanyahu, Prime Minister of Israel, to Address U.N. General Assembly
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will surely talk about the Iranian nuclear threat and the recent conflict with the militant group Hamas. He will likely link them to the threat posed by the Islamic State militant group.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Blocks Reports on Hong Kong Democracy Movement
item.description: Chinese censors block Instagram, and a directive from the central propaganda department in Beijing orders websites to delete any mention of the pro-democracy uprising in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A protester resting on a road in Hong Kong on Monday. Over the weekend, pro-democracy demonstrations turned into large street clashes that many Internet users in mainland China were unaware of because of censorship.

item.title: In Creating ‘Martyrs’ Day,’ China Promotes a Vision of the Past
item.description: As Beijing’s tensions with neighbors rise, analysts see Martyrs’ Day as an effort by the Communist Party to be seen as a guardian against invaders.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: A worker set up a red carpet on Monday at the Monument to the People's Heroes in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

item.title: Letter From America: A New Tactic for Youthful Defendants
item.description: Brooklyn, N.Y., is testing whether early police encounters can be reinvented as an opportunity to reach out to troubled youth and get them help.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: At War Blog: Helping Veterans Find Their Place, This Time on Campus
item.description: Organizations like the Posse Foundation are trying to bring more veterans to the nation’s elite four-year colleges and universities.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JACOB W. SOTAK

item.title: Chinese Court Sentences Teenagers to Death in Killing of Jume Tahir, Islamic Cleric
item.description: Prosecutors said the youths played key roles in the assassination this summer of Jume Tahir, an Islamic cleric in the western region of Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: The imam, Jume Tahir, 74, was killed on July 30.

item.title: Narendra Modi Outlines Goals for India on Eve of a Visit With Obama
item.description: At Madison Square Garden, Prime Minister Narendra Modi telegraphed a wish list while also deftly rallying an influential diaspora to his side.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Over 19,000 people at Madison Square Garden in New York chanted and roared for Narendra Modi, who was elected in May. Some wore white Modi T-shirts over their clothes.

item.title: U.S. and Philippines Hold Joint Military Exercises
item.description: The war games are being conducted amid a dispute over islets and outcroppings in the South China Sea claimed by both the Philippines and China.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Hong Kong Residents Defy Officials’ Call to End Protests
item.description: The city’s wave of public protest extended into the working week as thousands ignored a government call to abandon street blockades across the city.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Images of Hong Kong’s ‘Umbrella Revolution’ Tell a Story
item.description: Social media offered many images, both video and still, of the democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong. Here is a cross-section that captures the events.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Ashraf Ghani Sworn In as Afghan President
item.description: Mr. Ghani’s inauguration on Monday came under a cloud after a power-sharing agreement with the runner-up, Abdullah Abdullah, nearly collapsed.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, right, and the country's new chief executive, Abdullah Abdullah, at Mr. Ghani's swearing-in ceremony in the capital, Kabul, on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Warning in China: Beware the ‘Blue Fatty’ Cat
item.description: Three newspapers in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, have fired a salvo of accusations against the cartoon character Doraemon for its “political overtones” and being a tool of Japan’s “cultural invasion.”
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: A visitor photographs Doraemon dolls at a recent exhibit devoted to the popular Japanese cartoon character in Qingdao, Shandong Province.

item.title: In Kabul, Cuomo Seeks Insights on Terrorism
item.description: During a visit to Afghanistan, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo received briefings from military leaders that he said would inform his efforts to protect New York from terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and THOMAS KAPLAN
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, right, met with Maj. Gen. Stephen Townsend, second from left, during a tour of Bagram Airfield in Afghanistan on Sunday.

item.title: Nusra Front Vows Retaliation for Strikes in Syria
item.description: The leader of the Syrian rebel group and Qaeda offshoot threatens America in a YouTube video, a shift from the group’s prior focus on ousting Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMAD GHANNAM and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Crackdown on Protests by Hong Kong Police Draws More to the Streets
item.description: Downtown Hong Kong turned into a battlefield of tear gas and seething crowds on Sunday after the police moved against a student democracy protest.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG

item.title: Qaeda Group Attacks Shiite Base
item.description: A suicide bomber linked to Al Qaeda drove a car filled with explosives into a hospital used as a base by Yemen’s Shiite Muslim Houthi movement on Sunday, killing at least 15 people.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Bangkok Journal: You Call This Thai Food? The Robotic Taster Will Be the Judge
item.description: A boxy contraption scans food samples to produce a chemical signature, which it measures against a standard deemed to be that of authentic Thai food.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Giorgio Taraschi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sirapat Pratontep, an expert in nanotechnology who led the development of a machine that evaluates Thai food against a government standard.

item.title: Iraq Army Woos Deserters Back to War on ISIS
item.description: The Iraqi military command has launched a campaign to re-enlist soldiers and officers who abandoned their units.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: Shiite fighters training in the desert south of Baghdad on Thursday.

item.title: Taliban Press for Advantage as Politicians Work on Maneuvers in Kabul
item.description: A brutal battle in Ghazni Province was the latest sign that the insurgency was becoming increasingly ambitious, posing the central challenge facing the country’s new president.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and FAZL MUZHARY

item.title: At Madison Square Garden, Chants, Cheers and Roars for Modi
item.description: Narendra Modi, who spoke at Madison Square Garden on his first trip to the United States since being elected in May, was treated like a rock star.
item.dc:creator: By VIVIAN YEE
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India addressed a crowd at Madison Square Garden on Sunday.
